title: Measuring the Ocean
caption: The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) has hundreds of instruments collecting data every minute of every day from seven locations (arrays) throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Here we are looking at data from the Coastal Endurance location in the Temperate Pacific Ocean (red box).

title: The ocean off of the Pacific Northwest
caption: The Coastal Endurance location is in the ocean off of Oregon and Washington. There are many instruments at this location. Data in this activity were collected from the Central Oregon Line (red box).

title: What does it look like underwater?
caption: This drawing represents where the different instruments are attached to cables running from the surface down to the seafloor (i.e., a mooring) along the Central Oregon Line. Data in this activity were collected from instruments on the Oregon Shelf Surface Mooring (E, red box).

title: What is on the Mooring?
caption: The Near Surface Instrument Frame (red box) at 7m below the water surface is where the data for this activity were collected at the Shelf Surface Mooring. Many instruments, each collecting different oceanographic variable data, are included but data for this activity were collected using a Bulk Meteorology Instrument Package instrument.

title: How does a METBK work?
caption: The Bulk Meteorology Instrument Package measures different aspects of weather conditions above the sea surface, including data used to calculate movement of energy between the air and ocean. More information of how it works can be found here. The specific data in this activity are: Sea Surface Salinity, Air Temperature, Sea Surface Temperature, and Rain rate.
